unnormalised: The annual IIT entrance exam results sparked debate this yr, not just about cut-offs, but a new method of evaluating linear algebra skills. Reportedly, only 65% of candidates could correctly solve a basic matrix inversion problem, a core concept. Prof. Rao, head of the mathematics dept. at IIT Delhi, attributed this to an over-reliance on rote learning, "Students are memorising formulas instead of grasping the underlying principles. 3x3 matrix operations shouldn’t be a hurdle at this level."
normalised: The annual I-I-T entrance exam results sparked debate this year, not just about cut-offs, but a new method of evaluating linear algebra skills. Reportedly, only sixty five percent of candidates could correctly solve a basic matrix inversion problem, a core concept. Professor Rao, head of the mathematics department at I-I-T Delhi, attributed this to an over-reliance on rote learning, "Students are memorizing formulas instead of grasping the underlying principles. Three by three matrix operations shouldn't be a hurdle at this level."

unnormalised: The new method, inspired by research from ISI Kolkata, involved presenting the problems in a narrative format. Candidates had to translate a real-world scenario – say, calculating resource allocation given constraints - into a system of linear equations and then solve it. A mere 40% of students passed this section, highlighting a gap between theoretical knowledge & practical application. Many students scored well in the theory section with scores over 90/100 but struggled to apply the concepts.

unnormalised: Parents and educators are already calling for a revision of the curriculum, emphasizing problem-solving and conceptual understanding over memorization. Some coaching centers in Kota are adapting by introducing "situation-based learning" for complex mathematical problems. The use of software like MATLAB for matrix operations has also come under discussion, with some suggesting that students should be encouraged to use these tools after mastering the fundamentals.

unnormalised: The controversy has led to an increase in online resources and tutorials focusing on linear algebra applications, with platforms like Coursera offering specialized courses taught by faculty from top Indian institutions. Several experts have observed that success in exams now needs a blend of theory, numerical skills, and critical thinking. The pass percentage of 40% in linear algebra has become a wake-up call for the Indian education system.
